etymologies: early 20th century; earliest use found in Chemical Abstracts. From German Pelargonin from Pelargon- (in scientific Latin Pelargonium) + German -in

definitions: An anthocyanin (usually isolated as the red chloride, C₂₇ H₃₁ O₁₅ Cl) that is the colouring matter of zonal pelargoniums, and on hydrolysis gives pelargonidin and glucose.
